elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp030" view="all">(a) Molecular structure of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">meso</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">)</ce:sup>(DMF)] with the selected atom numbering scheme. (b) Enantiomers of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (red colored molecule) and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S</ce:sup>)(DMF)] (green colored molecule). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Molecular structure of [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] with the selected atom numbering scheme. (b) Enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] (red colored molecule) and [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] (green colored molecule). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp035" view="all">(a) One-dimensional chain structure of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">meso</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">)</ce:sup>(DMF)], running along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis, in which a Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion acts as a connector and the adjacent two molecules with opposite chiralities of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (green) are alternately linked. (b) A view projected onto the coordination planes, showing that the two enantiomers of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (green) are alternately arrayed in the 1D chain. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) One-dimensional chain structure of [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], running along the c-axis, in which a Na+ ion acts as a connector and the adjacent two molecules with opposite chiralities of [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] (green) are alternately linked. (b) A view projected onto the coordination planes, showing that the two enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] (green) are alternately arrayed in the 1D chain. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp040" view="all">Molecular structure of a linear Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2) unit with the selected atom numbering scheme. In the linear structure, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same enantiomorphs.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Molecular structure of a linear Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) unit with the selected atom numbering scheme. In the linear structure, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same enantiomorphs.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0030">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp045" view="all">A cyclic octanuclear structure formed by the hydrogen bonds through two water molecules (red ball). In the linear structure of the Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2) unit, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same chirality (red) and two Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes bridged by hydrogen bonds through water molecule have the opposite chirality (green). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  A cyclic octanuclear structure formed by the hydrogen bonds through two water molecules (red ball). In the linear structure of the Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) unit, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same chirality (red) and two CuII complexes bridged by hydrogen bonds through water molecule have the opposite chirality (green). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp050" view="all">The plots of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> and 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>, where <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The plots of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> follow the Curie–Weiss equation of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>−</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>)/<ce:italic>C</ce:italic> with a positive Weiss constant of <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>16.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The solid line represents the calculated curve with the fitted parameters of <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>(Gd)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.98, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>(Cu)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.19, <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+2.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>zJ</ce:italic>″<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−0.002<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  The plots of χ M T vs. T and 1/χ M vs. T, where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Cu2Gd2. The plots of 1/χ M vs. T follow the Curie-Weiss equation of 1/χ M =(T  -  θ)/C with a positive Weiss constant of θ =+2.8K and C =16.07cm3 Kmol-1. The solid line represents the calculated curve with the fitted parameters of g(Gd)=1.98, g(Cu)=2.19, J =+2.1cm-1, zJ"=-0.002cm-1, and R =5×10-5.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0040">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp055" view="all">The field dependence of the magnetization per Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> up to 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T at 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, as the plots of <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>Nβ</ce:italic> vs. <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>. The calculated curves of <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>Nβ</ce:italic> vs. <ce:italic>H</ce:italic> with the Brillouin functions of <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8 (ferromagnetic coupled tetramer (Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>)), <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (two ferromagnetic coupled Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>), and <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (independently existing two Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and two Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>) are drawn from the top line, and all calculation were performed with <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>197.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  The field dependence of the magnetization per Cu2Gd2 up to 5T at 2.0K, as the plots of M/Nβ vs. H. The calculated curves of M/Nβ vs. H with the Brillouin functions of S =8 (ferromagnetic coupled tetramer (CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII)), S =4×2 (two ferromagnetic coupled CuII-GdIII), and S =7/2×2+ S =1/2×2 (independently existing two CuII and two GdIII) are drawn from the top line, and all calculation were performed with g =197.

Graphical abstract

The CuII complex component [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] has a one-dimensional (1D) structure in which the diphenylethylenediamine moieties have the array of {(1R,2S)-Na-(1S,2R)}1∞. The assembly reaction of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )] and [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2] gives a linear tetranuclear complex of Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) with (1R,2S)-Gd(1)-(1R,2S)-Gd(2) or (1S,2R)-Gd(1)-(1S,2R)-Gd(2) and forms a hydrogen-bonded cyclic structure.

The assembly reaction of the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> components gave a linear complex with the array of Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2), in which two diphenylethylenediamine moieties have the same chirality of (1<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-(1<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>) or (1<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>)-(1<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>). elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A linear tetranuclear CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII complex [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2 was synthesized from the reaction of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] with [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2], and the structures and magnetic properties were investigated, where H3Ldpen(  meso  ) = meso-1,2-diphenyl-1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylideneamino)ethane and Hthd=2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedione. The CuII complex component [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] has a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, in which the Na+ ion is coordinated by two phenoxo and an ethoxy oxygen atoms of a CuII complex and an amido oxygen atom of the adjacent CuII unit to produce the 1D structure, in which the diphenylethylenediamine moieties have the array of {(1R,2S)-Na-(1S,2R)}1∞. The assembly reaction of the CuII and GdIII components gave a linear complex with the array of Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2), in which two diphenylethylenediamine moieties have the same chirality of (1R,2S)-(1R,2S) or (1S,2R)-(1S,2R). Two linear Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) units are linked by hydrogen bonds through two water molecules to give a cyclic structure with a center of symmetry. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities and field-dependent magnetization revealed the ferromagnetic interaction between the CuII and GdIII ions within the linear chain.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Since the discovery of single molecule magnets (SMMs) in Mn<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> clusters , a number of SMMs and single chain magnets (SCMs) of polynuclear transition–metal complexes have been synthesized . Since the pioneering work of Gatteschi and co-workers , a number of polynuclear Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> complexes with the magnetic isotropic Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion have been investigated . Over the last decade, the other transition metal–lanthanide complexes with the magnetic anisotropic lanthanide ion attracted a lot of attention because the magnetic anisotropy and high-spin state required for SMMs and SCMs can be easily provided by the f-element and d–f magnetic interactions, respectively . The assembly reactions of the d-component complex and the f-component complex are effective and adopted for the syntheses of d–f polynuclear complexes where the d- and f-component complexes function as donor and acceptor building blocks in the formation of coordination bonds, respectively .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the discovery of single molecule magnets (SMMs) in Mn12 clusters , a number of SMMs and single chain magnets (SCMs) of polynuclear transition-metal complexes have been synthesized . Since the pioneering work of Gatteschi and co-workers , a number of polynuclear CuII-GdIII complexes with the magnetic isotropic GdIII ion have been investigated . Over the last decade, the other transition metal-lanthanide complexes with the magnetic anisotropic lanthanide ion attracted a lot of attention because the magnetic anisotropy and high-spin state required for SMMs and SCMs can be easily provided by the f-element and d-f magnetic interactions, respectively . The assembly reactions of the d-component complex and the f-component complex are effective and adopted for the syntheses of d-f polynuclear complexes where the d- and f-component complexes function as donor and acceptor building blocks in the formation of coordination bonds, respectively .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Matsumoto and co-workers reported the first 3d–4f SMM with the formula of [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>LTb<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, which was derived from the assembly reaction of [KCu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L] and [Tb<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], where H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzyli-deneamino)ethylene and Hhfac<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hexafluoroacetylacetone . Since the d-component [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> functions as a bridging “<ce:italic>ligand-complex</ce:italic>” at the phenoxo site and the amide site and the f-component [Td(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> has vacant coordination sites, the resulting assembly structure is determined by the manner of assembly and the stereochemistry of the components. In fact, the assembly reaction gives [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>LLn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, in which Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> are alternately arrayed to form a cyclic tetranuclear [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] structure with a center of symmetry. As the resulting assembly structure must be determined by the manner of assembly and the stereochemistry of the components, modifications of the ligand can result in different assembly structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Matsumoto and co-workers reported the first 3d-4f SMM with the formula of [CuIILTbIII(hfac)2]2, which was derived from the assembly reaction of [KCuIIL] and [TbIII(hfac)3(H2O)2], where H3L=1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzyli-deneamino)ethylene and Hhfac=hexafluoroacetylacetone . Since the d-component [CuIIL]- functions as a bridging "ligand-complex" at the phenoxo site and the amide site and the f-component [Td(hfac)2]+ has vacant coordination sites, the resulting assembly structure is determined by the manner of assembly and the stereochemistry of the components. In fact, the assembly reaction gives [CuIILLnIII(hfac)2]2, in which CuII and LnIII are alternately arrayed to form a cyclic tetranuclear [CuII 2LnIII 2] structure with a center of symmetry. As the resulting assembly structure must be determined by the manner of assembly and the stereochemistry of the components, modifications of the ligand can result in different assembly structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Among the modifications of the components, chiral modifications can be effective for the formation of a new assembly structure. By introducing the chiral moiety to the component complex, selective syntheses of the cyclic cluster and the 1D chain complexes, which can show SMM and SCM properties, can be generated. The possible reaction procedures are given in

The possible reaction procedures are given in  .

elements.clean_text: In this study, a chiral d-component of [CuIILdpen(1S,2S)]-, instead of [CuIIL]-, was used in order to break the center of symmetry of the cyclic structure. As anticipated, a chiral ferromagnetic chain structure of the CuII-GdIII complex [CuIILdpen(1S,2S)GdIII(thd)2] n  was obtained, demonstrating that the introduction of the chiral moiety to the component is an effective way to generate a distinctly different assembly structure. In this study, instead of the (1S,2S) or (1R,2R) form in the 1,2-diphenylethylenediamine moiety [NaCuIILdpen(1S,2S)] or [NaCuIILdpen(1R,2R)], the meso-form [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )] was used as a chiral component. The molecular structures of the ligands are shown in  . The assembly reaction of [NaCuIIH3Ldpen(  meso  )] with [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2] was studied, where H3Ldpen(  meso  ) = meso-1,2-diphenyl-1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylideneamino)ethane. We report on the synthesis, structure and magnetic properties.

Experimental

Syntheses

Materials

All chemicals and solvents used for the syntheses were reagent grade and were obtained from Tokyo Kasei Co., Ltd. and Wako Co., Ltd. and used without further purification. The GdIII complex component [Gd(thd)3(H2O)2] was purchased from Wako Co., Ltd.

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>. The ligand was prepared by a two-step reaction procedure as follows. A solution of <ce:italic>meso</ce:italic>-diphenylethylenediamine (2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of <ce:italic>iso</ce:italic>-propanol was added to a solution of phenylsalicylate (2.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of <ce:italic>iso</ce:italic>-propanol at room temperature. The mixed solution was refluxed for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and then cooled to room temperature. A solution of 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde (2.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of methanol was added to the mixed solution at room temperature and then refluxed for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The resulting solution was evaporated to oily material and then dissolved in a minimum amount of dichloromethane. The mixture was separated by column chromatography on silica gel (Fuji Silicia BW-300SP) eluted with dichloromethane. The first yellow fraction was the by-product and the second orange fraction was the ligand. The orange fraction was collected and evaporated to oily material. To the oily material, 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of diethyl ether was added and the solution was stirred for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. Yellow crystalline materials precipitated and were collected by suction filtration. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>

elements.clean_text:
meso-1,2-Diphenyl-1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylideneamino)-ethane, H3Ldpen(  meso  ) 

The unsymmetrical ligand abbreviated as H3Ldpen(  meso  ) is the 1:1:1 condensation reaction of phenylsalicylate, meso-diphenylethylenediamine, and 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde, according to the reaction procedure of  . The ligand was prepared by a two-step reaction procedure as follows. A solution of meso-diphenylethylenediamine (2.5g, 12mmol) in 50mL of iso-propanol was added to a solution of phenylsalicylate (2.57g, 12mmol) in 50mL of iso-propanol at room temperature. The mixed solution was refluxed for 15h and then cooled to room temperature. A solution of 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde (2.00g, 12mmol) in 50mL of methanol was added to the mixed solution at room temperature and then refluxed for 1h. The resulting solution was evaporated to oily material and then dissolved in a minimum amount of dichloromethane. The mixture was separated by column chromatography on silica gel (Fuji Silicia BW-300SP) eluted with dichloromethane. The first yellow fraction was the by-product and the second orange fraction was the ligand. The orange fraction was collected and evaporated to oily material. To the oily material, 30mL of diethyl ether was added and the solution was stirred for 15min. Yellow crystalline materials precipitated and were collected by suction filtration. Anal. Calc. for H3Ldpen(  meso  ) =C30H28N2O4: C, 74.98; H, 5.87; N, 5.83. Found: C, 75.14; H, 5.96; N, 5.83%. 1H NMR (500MHz, CDCl3, 298K): δ =13.35 (OH, s, 1H), 11.97 (OH, s, 1H), 8.36 (amine, s, 1H), 6.7-7.4 (Ph, m, 17H), 5.56 (ethylenediamine, t, 1H), 4.98 (ethylenediamine, t, 1H), 4.13 (ethoxy, q, 2H), 1.56 (ethoxy, t, 3H) ppm. M.p. 193.4°C.

A solution of copper(II) acetate monohydrate (42mg, 0.21mmol) in 10mL of methanol was added to a solution of H3Ldpen(  meso  ) (100mg, 0.21mmol) in 10mL of methanol. The mixed solution was warmed on a hot plate with stirring for 30min and then an aqueous solution of 1M NaOH (0.63mmol) was added and the resulting solution was stirred for a further 1h at room temperature. <ce:section-title>Methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Elemental C, H, and N analyses were carried out at the Instrumental Analysis Center of Kumamoto University. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 370 DTGS spectrometer using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a TG/DTA6200 (Seiko Instrument Inc.), where the samples were heated from room temperature to 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Temperature-dependent dc magnetic susceptibilities in the temperature range of 2.0–300.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and field-dependent magnetization under an applied magnetic field from 0 to 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T at 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K were measured using an MPMS-5S SQUID susceptometer (Quantum Design, Inc.) at Kumamoto University. The calibrations were performed with palladium. Corrections for diamagnetism were applied using Pascal’s constants . The magnetic data per Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were calculated on the basis of the chemical formula of [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">meso</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">)</ce:sup>Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(thd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Methods

Elemental C, H, and N analyses were carried out at the Instrumental Analysis Center of Kumamoto University. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 370 DTGS spectrometer using KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a TG/DTA6200 (Seiko Instrument Inc.), where the samples were heated from room temperature to 150°C. Temperature-dependent dc magnetic susceptibilities in the temperature range of 2.0-300.0K and field-dependent magnetization under an applied magnetic field from 0 to 5T at 2.0K were measured using an MPMS-5S SQUID susceptometer (Quantum Design, Inc.) at Kumamoto University. The calibrations were performed with palladium. Corrections for diamagnetism were applied using Pascal's constants . The magnetic data per Cu2Gd2 were calculated on the basis of the chemical formula of [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2⋅3H2O.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The X-ray diffraction data of the CuII component complex and the CuII-GdIII complex were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID imaging plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ =71073Å). Large brown block crystals of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] were subjected to X-ray analysis at 296K. Despite many attempts to grow crystals that were large enough, the size of the crystals of the CuII-GdIII complex obtained was small. The crystals were confirmed by elemental analyses, and then a crystal from the same vessel was used for X-ray analysis at 200K. Due to the small size of the crystal, with the dimensions of 0.08×0.05×0.01mm3 and many parameters, two out of five water molecules in [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2 were determined by X-ray analysis. The data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization, and absorption effects. The temperature of the crystal was maintained at the selected value by means of a Rigaku cooling device with an accuracy of ±2K. The structures were solved by direct methods and expanded using the Fourier technique. For [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, whereas hydrogen atoms were fixed at the calculated positions and refined using a riding model. For [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2, the Cu and Gd atoms were refined anisotropically, whereas the other atoms were refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms were not included in the calculation. Isotropic atomic displacement parameters, especially for some tert-butyl groups of the thd ligands, were large because of the poor crystal quality. All calculations were performed using the Crystal Structure crystallographic software package . The atomic scattering factors and anomalous dispersion terms were taken from the standard compilation. The crystallographic data are summarized below and the relevant bond distances are given in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Syntheses

The unsymmetrical tetradentate ligand abbreviated as H3Ldpen(  meso  ) is the 1:1:1 condensation product of phenylsalicylate, meso-diphenylethylenediamine, and 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde. The ligand was prepared by a stepwise reaction procedure, purified by column chromatography on silica gel eluted with dichloromethane, and obtained as yellow crystals, as described in the Section . The CuII complex [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH was synthesized by the reaction of the ligand, copper(II) acetate monohydrate, and sodium hydroxide at a 1:1:3 molar ratio in methanol. The crude product was recrystallized from DMF to give the complex [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] as deep-red block crystals. The assembly reaction of [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH and [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2] (Hthd=2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedione) resulted in crystals of a CuII-GdIII complex with the formula [CuLdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2⋅3H2O and appearing as small thin-plate red crystals. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the Cu-Gd complex was performed. On elevating the temperature at the heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 up to 150°C, the 2.5% weight loss corresponding to three crystal water molecules was observed. On keeping temperature at 150°C, the gradual weight loss corresponding to one water molecule assignable to the hydrogen bonded water in a cyclic structure was observed. The fifth water molecule coordinated to GdIII ion was not eliminated under the present condition. The TGA result agrees with the elemental analysis and the X-ray analysis.

The Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion has a square-planar coordination geometry with N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> donor atoms of a trinegative tetradentate ligand (L<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>

</ce:italic>)<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>. The coordination bond distances are Cu−O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.910(2), Cu−O(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.881(2), Cu−N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.940(2), and Cu−N(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.901(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, in which the Cu−O(1) and Cu−N(1) bond distances at the 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde moiety are longer than their corresponding values of Cu−O(2) and Cu−N(2) at the 2-hydroxybenzamido moiety, respectively, demonstrating that the NO donors of the 2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylidene group give a weaker ligand field than that of 2-hydroxybenzamido.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)]

The CuII complex crystallizes in a centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c and the crystallographically unique unit consists of one Na+ cation, one complex anion [CuLdpen(  meso  )]-, and one DMF molecule. As the complex crystallizes into the centrosymmetric space group, the crystal involves two enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)].   shows the molecular structures of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] with the selected atom numbering scheme, showing how two complex anions are related by a mirror. The CuII ion has a square-planar coordination geometry with N2O2 donor atoms of a trinegative tetradentate ligand (Ldpen(  meso )3-. The coordination bond distances are Cu-O(1)=1.910(2), Cu-O(2)=1.881(2), Cu-N(1)=1.940(2), and Cu-N(2)=1.901(2)Å, in which the Cu-O(1) and Cu-N(1) bond distances at the 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde moiety are longer than their corresponding values of Cu-O(2) and Cu-N(2) at the 2-hydroxybenzamido moiety, respectively, demonstrating that the NO donors of the 2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylidene group give a weaker ligand field than that of 2-hydroxybenzamido.

elements.clean_text: As shown in , the Na+ cation is coordinated by two phenoxo and one ethoxy oxygen atoms of a CuII complex. The Na+ ion is coordinated in total by five oxygen atoms consisting of two phenoxo oxygen atoms O(1), O(2) and one ethoxy oxygen atom O(3), one oxygen atom O(5) of DMF molecule, and an amido oxygen atom O(4)∗ of an adjacent anion-complex [CuLdpen(  meso  )]-. These distances are Na-O(1)=2.302(3), Na-O(2)=2.356(3), Na-O(3)=2.598(3), Na-O(4)∗ =2.243(3), and Na-O(5)=2.320(3)Å. Among the five Na-O distances, the distance of Na-O(4)∗ =2.243(3)Å between an Na+ ion and the amido oxygen atom O(4)∗ of the adjacent molecule is the shortest. As a result of the Na-O(4)∗ bond, the CuII complex forms a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure as shown in  . The compound is best described as [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], which represents the repeating unit of the 1D chain.

<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">At this stage, it is proper to describe the sequence of the enantiomorphs in the 1D chain. The present complex anion [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>

In the crystal lattice, two chiral species of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S)</ce:sup>(DMF)] and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] coexist. Within a zigzag chain, the two adjacent molecules are related by a symmetry operation of the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-glide plane, so that two enantiomers of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S)</ce:sup>(DMF)] and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] are alternately linked by a Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion to result in an achiral one-dimensional zigzag chain, as shown in (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: At this stage, it is proper to describe the sequence of the enantiomorphs in the 1D chain. The present complex anion [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] has two enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)], where H3Ldpen(1R,2S) denotes 1R,2S-diphenyl-1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylideneamino)ethane and H3Ldpen(1S,2R) denotes 1S,2R-diphenyl-1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylideneamino)ethane. In the crystal lattice, two chiral species of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] coexist. Within a zigzag chain, the two adjacent molecules are related by a symmetry operation of the c-glide plane, so that two enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] are alternately linked by a Na+ ion to result in an achiral one-dimensional zigzag chain, as shown in (b).

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2 

This complex was obtained as thin-plate crystals. The single crystal X-ray diffraction study was performed at 200K using a small-sized crystal with the dimensions of 0.08×0.05×0.01mm3. The overall structure was obtained but, due to the small size of the crystal and many atomic parameters of the tetrameric molecule, the quality of the X-ray result was poor, especially at the tert-butyl groups of the thd ligands. Two water molecules per crystallographically unique CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII unit, where one is coordinated to the GdIII ion and another is fixed by hydrogen bonds in the cyclic structure, are located, but the other crystal water molecules were not found. The CuII-GdIII complex crystallizes in a centrosymmetric triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     and the crystallographically unique unit consists of a linear tetrameric unit [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)] and one H2O molecule.   shows the structure of the unique unit with the selected atom numbering scheme, showing the linear structure of Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2), in which two CuII complexes have the same enantiomorphs, that is, two [CuLdpen(1S,2R)]- or two [CuLdpen(1R,2S)]-. The CuII complex functions as a "bridging ligand-complex", in which two phenoxo and one ethoxy oxygen atoms at one side of the planar CuII complex coordinate to a GdIII ion as a tridentate ligand for both Cu(1) and Cu(2). The amido oxygen atom on the opposite side of the CuII complex Cu(2) coordinates to the GdIII ion as a monodentate ligand, whereas the amido oxygen O(3) of Cu(1) is free from coordination and is hydrogen bonded to a water molecule O(18). For both Gd(1) and Gd(2), each GdIII ion has an octacoordinate geometry with O8 oxygen atoms, including four oxygen atoms of two thd didentate chelate ligands and three oxygen atoms from a [CuLdpen(  meso  )]-. For Gd(1), the eighth oxygen atom is the amide oxygen atom O(11) from the adjacent [Cu(Ldpen(  meso  ))]- with Gd(1)-O(11)=2.34Å and for Gd(2) the eight oxygen atom is the coordinated water molecule O(17) with Gd(2)-O(17)=2.46(2)Å.

As shown in

The Cu−Gd distances in the Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2) units are 3.448(3), 6.198(3), and 3.378(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu(1)−Gd(1), Gd(1)−Cu(2), and Cu(2)−Gd(2), respectively. The distance between Cu(1) and Gd(2)<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> is 9.213<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>

As shown in  , including the hydrogen bonds, a cyclic octanuclear structure is displayed with a center of symmetry, in which Cu and Gd ions are alternately arrayed and the array of enantiomorphs of the CuII sites are [(1R,2S)-(1R,2S)⋯(1S, 2R)-(1S,2R)]. The Cu-Gd distances in the Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) units are 3.448(3), 6.198(3), and 3.378(3)Å for Cu(1)-Gd(1), Gd(1)-Cu(2), and Cu(2)-Gd(2), respectively. The distance between Cu(1) and Gd(2)∗ is 9.213Å.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties of [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2⋅3H2O

The temperature dependences of the magnetic susceptibility were measured in the temperature range of 2.0-300.0K under the external magnetic field of 0.5T.   shows the plots of χ M T versus T, where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Cu2Gd2 unit and T is the absolute temperature. The χ M T values at 300.0K are 16.23cm3 Kmol-1, this value being slightly smaller than the calculated value of 16.5cm3 Kmol-1 expected for two CuII (S =1/2, g =2.00) and two GdIII (4f 7, J =7/2, L =0, S =7/2, 8S7/2) non-interacting ions. On lowering the temperature from 300.0K to 2.0K, the χ M T value gradually increases to reach a maximum value of 20.78cm3 Kmol-1 at 6.0K, and then slightly decreases to 19.05cm3 Kmol-1 at 2.0K. The increase of the χ M T value in the higher temperature region indicates the operation of a ferromagnetic interaction between CuII and GdIII ions, while the slight decrease in the lower temperature region can be ascribed to a weak intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction, probably related to the hydrogen bond between two tetrameric units. The 1/χ M versus T plots over the whole temperature range of 2.0-300.0K follow the Curie-Weiss equation of 1/χ M =(T - θ)/C with a positive Weiss constant of θ =+2.8K and C =16.07cm3 Kmol-1.

elements.clean_text: Since the ground state of the GdIII ion (8S7/2) has no contribution from orbital angular momentum, the magnetic susceptibility of the CuII 2GdIII 2 complex can be reproduced by the equation derived from the spin-only Hamiltonian  H  = g Cu β(S Cu1 + S Cu2) H + g Gd β(S Gd1 + S Gd2)⋅H -2J 1(S Cu1 S Gd1 + S Cu2 S Gd2)-2J 2(S Gd1 S Cu2) based on the coupling scheme for the linear CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII tetranuclear structure, as reported below:   Cu ( 1 )   -     J   1     Gd ( 1 )   -     J   2     Cu ( 2 )   -     J   1     Gd ( 2 )   where g Cu and g Gd are the g-factors for the GdIII and CuII ions, H is the applied magnetic field, J 1 is the Heisenberg coupling constant between the outer and central CuII and GdIII ions (through two phenoxo monoatomic bridges) while J 2 is the Heisenberg coupling constant between the central CuII and GdIII ions (through a three atom N-C-O bridge). Although the linear CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII unit does not show any crystallographic symmetry, the same coupling constant J 1 was assumed for the terminal Cu1-Gd1 and Cu2-Gd2 magnetic interactions on the basis of similar geometric features for these diphenoxo-bridged binuclear subunits. The magnetic susceptibility at each temperature was calculated using the theoretical equation χ = M/H =[NΣi (-dE i/dH)exp(-E i/kT)]/[HΣ i exp(-E i/kT). The energy levels of the tetramer, E i, were evaluated by diagonalizing the Hamiltonian matrix (with dimensions 256×256) in the uncoupled spin function basis set. Moreover, a molecular field term -zJ'< S z > S z was added to the Hamiltonian to describe the molecular interactions between the tetrameric units. Although small, these interactions are necessary to reproduce the decrease in the magnetic moment below 4K. The final expression for the magnetic susceptibility becomes, χ mf = χ/[1- zJ'χ/Ng2β2], where χ is the magnetic susceptibility for the isolated tetramer, calculated as described above.

<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">Preliminary fits performed with this Hamiltonian indicate vanishingly small values of <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and large standard errors for this parameter suggest that the magnetic interaction between the central Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions can be reasonably neglected. This approximation corresponds to the consideration of the tetramer as two independent Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> binuclear units and leads to stable four parameter fits in excellent agreement with the experimental magnetic susceptibility data. The solid line in  shows the theoretical curve with the best-fit parameters: <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+2.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>zJ</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−0.002<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, with an agreement factor <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup>. These results indicate that a significant ferromagnetic interaction operates between the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ions through two phenoxo bridges while a negligible interaction occurs though a three atom N–C–O bridge. The calculated curve with the best-fit parameters is shown in  as the solid line.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Preliminary fits performed with this Hamiltonian indicate vanishingly small values of J 2 and large standard errors for this parameter suggest that the magnetic interaction between the central GdIII and CuII ions can be reasonably neglected. This approximation corresponds to the consideration of the tetramer as two independent CuIIGdIII binuclear units and leads to stable four parameter fits in excellent agreement with the experimental magnetic susceptibility data. The solid line in  shows the theoretical curve with the best-fit parameters: g Cu =2.19, g Gd =1.98, J 1 =+2.1cm-1 and zJ'=-0.002cm-1, with an agreement factor R =9.5×10-5. These results indicate that a significant ferromagnetic interaction operates between the CuII and GdIII ions through two phenoxo bridges while a negligible interaction occurs though a three atom N-C-O bridge. The calculated curve with the best-fit parameters is shown in  as the solid line.

elements.clean_text: The field dependence of the magnetization up to 5T at 2.0K is shown in  , as the plots of M/Nβ versus H. The experimental data per Cu2Gd2 are much higher than the calculated curve of the Brillouin function of S =7/2×2+ S =1/2×2 (independently existing two CuII and two GdIII) and significantly lower than the calculated Brillouin function for a S =8 spin state (with g =2.0) expected from a complete ferromagnetic coupling of all of the ions within the CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII tetramer: see the broken line in . The data are instead quite close to the theoretical curve for two S =4 spin states, the situation expected for the ferromagnetic coupling of the CuII and GdIII ions within two independent CuII-GdIII dimers, in good agreement with the results of the magnetic susceptibility data analysis above. Indeed, a reasonably good fit of the experimental data to the Brillouin function for two S =4 spin states was obtained with g =1.97: see the solid curve in .

The (1S,2S) compound has an infinite chain structure of the alternately arrayed CuII and GdIII ions, the Curie-Weiss constant of θ =+8.8K is larger than the meso-compound, and the field-dependent magnetization at 2.0K is larger than the calculated curve of the Brillouin function of the ferromagnetically coupled GdIII-CuII-GdIII-CuII tetramer.

<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The chiral effect of the assembly reaction between the d- and f-components exhibiting donor and acceptor coordination abilities, respectively, was examined by the reaction of [NaCu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">meso</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">)</ce:sup>] and [Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(thd)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. The assembly reaction gave a linear complex with the array of Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2), in which two diphenylethylenediamine moieties have the same chirality of (1<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-Gd(1)-(1<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>) or (1<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>)-Gd(1)-(1<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>), while the reaction between [NaCu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2S)</ce:sup>] and [Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(thd)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] produced a chiral infinite chain complex [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2S)</ce:sup>Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(thd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">1∞</ce:inf> with {(1<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>,2<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-Gd}<ce:inf loc="post">1∞</ce:inf>, and, furthermore, a similar assembly reaction using the achiral complex [NaCu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>L] gave a cyclic structure {–Cu–Gd–}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. These results demonstrate that chirality is effective for the formation of very different assembly structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The chiral effect of the assembly reaction between the d- and f-components exhibiting donor and acceptor coordination abilities, respectively, was examined by the reaction of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )] and [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2]. The assembly reaction gave a linear complex with the array of Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2), in which two diphenylethylenediamine moieties have the same chirality of (1R,2S)-Gd(1)-(1R,2S) or (1S,2R)-Gd(1)-(1S,2R), while the reaction between [NaCuIILdpen(1S,2S)] and [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2] produced a chiral infinite chain complex [CuIILdpen(1S,2S)GdIII(thd)2]1∞ with {(1S,2S)-Gd}1∞, and, furthermore, a similar assembly reaction using the achiral complex [NaCuIIL] gave a cyclic structure {-Cu-Gd-}2. These results demonstrate that chirality is effective for the formation of very different assembly structures.

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>. The ligand was prepared by a two-step reaction procedure as follows. A solution of <ce:italic>meso</ce:italic>-diphenylethylenediamine (2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of <ce:italic>iso</ce:italic>-propanol was added to a solution of phenylsalicylate (2.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of <ce:italic>iso</ce:italic>-propanol at room temperature. The mixed solution was refluxed for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and then cooled to room temperature. A solution of 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde (2.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of methanol was added to the mixed solution at room temperature and then refluxed for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The resulting solution was evaporated to oily material and then dissolved in a minimum amount of dichloromethane. The mixture was separated by column chromatography on silica gel (Fuji Silicia BW-300SP) eluted with dichloromethane. The first yellow fraction was the by-product and the second orange fraction was the ligand. The orange fraction was collected and evaporated to oily material. To the oily material, 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of diethyl ether was added and the solution was stirred for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. meso-1,2-Diphenyl-1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-(2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylideneamino)-ethane, H3Ldpen(  meso  ) 

The unsymmetrical ligand abbreviated as H3Ldpen(  meso  ) is the 1:1:1 condensation reaction of phenylsalicylate, meso-diphenylethylenediamine, and 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde, according to the reaction procedure of  . The ligand was prepared by a two-step reaction procedure as follows. A solution of meso-diphenylethylenediamine (2.5g, 12mmol) in 50mL of iso-propanol was added to a solution of phenylsalicylate (2.57g, 12mmol) in 50mL of iso-propanol at room temperature. The mixed solution was refluxed for 15h and then cooled to room temperature. A solution of 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde (2.00g, 12mmol) in 50mL of methanol was added to the mixed solution at room temperature and then refluxed for 1h. The resulting solution was evaporated to oily material and then dissolved in a minimum amount of dichloromethane. The mixture was separated by column chromatography on silica gel (Fuji Silicia BW-300SP) eluted with dichloromethane. The first yellow fraction was the by-product and the second orange fraction was the ligand. The orange fraction was collected and evaporated to oily material. To the oily material, 30mL of diethyl ether was added and the solution was stirred for 15min. Yellow crystalline materials precipitated and were collected by suction filtration. Anal. Calc. for H3Ldpen(  meso  ) =C30H28N2O4: C, 74.98; H, 5.87; N, 5.83. Found: C, 75.14; H, 5.96; N, 5.83%. 1H NMR (500MHz, CDCl3, 298K): δ =13.35 (OH, s, 1H), 11.97 (OH, s, 1H), 8.36 (amine, s, 1H), 6.7-7.4 (Ph, m, 17H), 5.56 (ethylenediamine, t, 1H), 4.98 (ethylenediamine, t, 1H), 4.13 (ethoxy, q, 2H), 1.56 (ethoxy, t, 3H) ppm. M.p. 193.4°C.

[NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH

A solution of copper(II) acetate monohydrate (42mg, 0.21mmol) in 10mL of methanol was added to a solution of H3Ldpen(  meso  ) (100mg, 0.21mmol) in 10mL of methanol. The mixed solution was warmed on a hot plate with stirring for 30min and then an aqueous solution of 1M NaOH (0.63mmol) was added and the resulting solution was stirred for a further 1h at room temperature. The solution was evaporated to dryness to give a pale brown material. This material was suspended in 100mL of CH3CN and stirred for 30min on a hot plate. The suspension was then filtered. Red-brown block crystals precipitated from the filtrate during the slow evaporation process and they were collected by suction filtration. Yield: 0.053g (45%). Anal. Calc. for [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH=C30H25N2O4CuNa⋅0.5MeOH: C, 63.15; H, 4.69; N, 4.82. Found: C, 63.51; H, 5.05; N, 5.14%; FAB-MS: m/z: 564.2 (M).

[CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2⋅3H2O

A solution of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH (0.10g, 0.167mmol) in 20mL of chloroform was added to a solution of [Gd(thd)3(H2O)2] (0.13g, 0.167mmol) in 20mL of chloroform, and the mixed solution was warmed for 4h. The resulting solution was evaporated to dryness. The crude product was dissolved in methanol and filtered. The filtrate was allowed to stand for several days, during which time brown square block crystals precipitated. Yield: 0.03g (17%). Anal. Calc. for CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2⋅2.5H2O=C52H63N2O8CuGd⋅2.5H2O: C, 56.27; H, 6.17; N, 2.52. Found: C, 56.28; H, 6.08; N, 2.69%. FAB-MS: m/z: 1065.3 (M), 1945.5 ([M2 - (thd) - (H2O)2]+).

Results and discussion

Syntheses

The unsymmetrical tetradentate ligand abbreviated as H3Ldpen(  meso  ) is the 1:1:1 condensation product of phenylsalicylate, meso-diphenylethylenediamine, and 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde. The ligand was prepared by a stepwise reaction procedure, purified by column chromatography on silica gel eluted with dichloromethane, and obtained as yellow crystals, as described in the Section . The CuII complex [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH was synthesized by the reaction of the ligand, copper(II) acetate monohydrate, and sodium hydroxide at a 1:1:3 molar ratio in methanol. The crude product was recrystallized from DMF to give the complex [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] as deep-red block crystals. The assembly reaction of [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH and [GdIII(thd)3(H2O)2] (Hthd=2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedione) resulted in crystals of a CuII-GdIII complex with the formula [CuLdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2⋅3H2O and appearing as small thin-plate red crystals. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the Cu-Gd complex was performed. On elevating the temperature at the heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 up to 150°C, the 2.5% weight loss corresponding to three crystal water molecules was observed. On keeping temperature at 150°C, the gradual weight loss corresponding to one water molecule assignable to the hydrogen bonded water in a cyclic structure was observed. The fifth water molecule coordinated to GdIII ion was not eliminated under the present condition. The TGA result agrees with the elemental analysis and the X-ray analysis.

[NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)]

Complex [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )]⋅0.5MeOH was recrystallized from N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) to produce large brown block crystals suitable for an X-ray diffraction study. Anal. Calc. for [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)]=C33H32N3O5CuNa: C, 62.21; H, 5.06; N, 6.59. Found: C, 62.49; H, 5.27; N, 6.67%.

X-ray crystallography

The X-ray diffraction data of the CuII component complex and the CuII-GdIII complex were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID imaging plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ =71073Å). Large brown block crystals of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)] were subjected to X-ray analysis at 296K. Despite many attempts to grow crystals that were large enough, the size of the crystals of the CuII-GdIII complex obtained was small. The crystals were confirmed by elemental analyses, and then a crystal from the same vessel was used for X-ray analysis at 200K. Due to the small size of the crystal, with the dimensions of 0.08×0.05×0.01mm3 and many parameters, two out of five water molecules in [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2 were determined by X-ray analysis. The data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization, and absorption effects. The temperature of the crystal was maintained at the selected value by means of a Rigaku cooling device with an accuracy of ±2K. The structures were solved by direct methods and expanded using the Fourier technique. For [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, whereas hydrogen atoms were fixed at the calculated positions and refined using a riding model. For [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2, the Cu and Gd atoms were refined anisotropically, whereas the other atoms were refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms were not included in the calculation. Isotropic atomic displacement parameters, especially for some tert-butyl groups of the thd ligands, were large because of the poor crystal quality. All calculations were performed using the Crystal Structure crystallographic software package . The atomic scattering factors and anomalous dispersion terms were taken from the standard compilation. The crystallographic data are summarized below and the relevant bond distances are given in  .

[NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], formula=C33H33N3O5CuNa, M =638.18, monoclinic, space group= P21/c (No. 14), a =9.615(2), b =22.500(6), c =14.261(5)Å, β =95.527(13)°, V =3071(1)Å3, Z =4, D calc =1.380gcm-3, μ(MoKα)=0.7707mm-1, T =296K, R with I >2.0, σ(I)=0.0443, wR(F 2) with all data=0.1028.

[CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2, formula=C104H130Cu2Gd2N4O18, M =2165.70, T =200(2)K, triclinic, space group=   P   1   ¯    , a =14.2599(13)Å, b =20.9551(18)Å, c =22.345(2)Å, α =61.074(2)°, β =70.064(2)°, γ =81.138(3)°, V =5493.4(8)Å3, Z =2, D calc =1.309cm-3, μ(MoKα)=1.635mm-1, crystal size=0.08×0.05×0.01mm3, reflections collected 54164, independent reflections 24776 [R int =0.2337], R 1 =0.1837, wR 2 =0.4125.

Structural description of [NaCuIILdpen(  meso  )(DMF)]

The CuII complex crystallizes in a centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c and the crystallographically unique unit consists of one Na+ cation, one complex anion [CuLdpen(  meso  )]-, and one DMF molecule. As the complex crystallizes into the centrosymmetric space group, the crystal involves two enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)].   shows the molecular structures of [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] and [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] with the selected atom numbering scheme, showing how two complex anions are related by a mirror. The CuII ion has a square-planar coordination geometry with N2O2 donor atoms of a trinegative tetradentate ligand (Ldpen(  meso )3-. The coordination bond distances are Cu-O(1)=1.910(2), Cu-O(2)=1.881(2), Cu-N(1)=1.940(2), and Cu-N(2)=1.901(2)Å, in which the Cu-O(1) and Cu-N(1) bond distances at the 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde moiety are longer than their corresponding values of Cu-O(2) and Cu-N(2) at the 2-hydroxybenzamido moiety, respectively, demonstrating that the NO donors of the 2-hydroxy-3-ethoxybenzylidene group give a weaker ligand field than that of 2-hydroxybenzamido.

As shown in , the Na+ cation is coordinated by two phenoxo and one ethoxy oxygen atoms of a CuII complex. The Na+ ion is coordinated in total by five oxygen atoms consisting of two phenoxo oxygen atoms O(1), O(2) and one ethoxy oxygen atom O(3), one oxygen atom O(5) of DMF molecule, and an amido oxygen atom O(4)∗ of an adjacent anion-complex [CuLdpen(  meso  )]-. These distances are Na-O(1)=2.302(3), Na-O(2)=2.356(3), Na-O(3)=2.598(3), Na-O(4)∗ =2.243(3), and Na-O(5)=2.320(3)Å. Among the five Na-O distances, the distance of Na-O(4)∗ =2.243(3)Å between an Na+ ion and the amido oxygen atom O(4)∗ of the adjacent molecule is the shortest. As a result of the Na-O(4)∗ bond, the CuII complex forms a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure as shown in  . The compound is best described as [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], which represents the repeating unit of the 1D chain.

Crystal structure of [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2 

This complex was obtained as thin-plate crystals. The single crystal X-ray diffraction study was performed at 200K using a small-sized crystal with the dimensions of 0.08×0.05×0.01mm3. The overall structure was obtained but, due to the small size of the crystal and many atomic parameters of the tetrameric molecule, the quality of the X-ray result was poor, especially at the tert-butyl groups of the thd ligands. Two water molecules per crystallographically unique CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII unit, where one is coordinated to the GdIII ion and another is fixed by hydrogen bonds in the cyclic structure, are located, but the other crystal water molecules were not found. The CuII-GdIII complex crystallizes in a centrosymmetric triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     and the crystallographically unique unit consists of a linear tetrameric unit [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)] and one H2O molecule.   shows the structure of the unique unit with the selected atom numbering scheme, showing the linear structure of Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2), in which two CuII complexes have the same enantiomorphs, that is, two [CuLdpen(1S,2R)]- or two [CuLdpen(1R,2S)]-. The CuII complex functions as a "bridging ligand-complex", in which two phenoxo and one ethoxy oxygen atoms at one side of the planar CuII complex coordinate to a GdIII ion as a tridentate ligand for both Cu(1) and Cu(2). The amido oxygen atom on the opposite side of the CuII complex Cu(2) coordinates to the GdIII ion as a monodentate ligand, whereas the amido oxygen O(3) of Cu(1) is free from coordination and is hydrogen bonded to a water molecule O(18). For both Gd(1) and Gd(2), each GdIII ion has an octacoordinate geometry with O8 oxygen atoms, including four oxygen atoms of two thd didentate chelate ligands and three oxygen atoms from a [CuLdpen(  meso  )]-. For Gd(1), the eighth oxygen atom is the amide oxygen atom O(11) from the adjacent [Cu(Ldpen(  meso  ))]- with Gd(1)-O(11)=2.34Å and for Gd(2) the eight oxygen atom is the coordinated water molecule O(17) with Gd(2)-O(17)=2.46(2)Å.

Two linear Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) units are linked by two water molecules O(18) and O(18)∗, where the amide oxygen atom O(3) of Cu(1) is hydrogen bonded to O(18) with a distance of O(3)⋯O(18)=2.76Å, and O(18) is further hydrogen bonded to the coordinated water molecule O(17) of Gd(2) with a distance of O(17)⋯O(18)=2.67Å. As shown in  , including the hydrogen bonds, a cyclic octanuclear structure is displayed with a center of symmetry, in which Cu and Gd ions are alternately arrayed and the array of enantiomorphs of the CuII sites are [(1R,2S)-(1R,2S)⋯(1S, 2R)-(1S,2R)]. The Cu-Gd distances in the Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) units are 3.448(3), 6.198(3), and 3.378(3)Å for Cu(1)-Gd(1), Gd(1)-Cu(2), and Cu(2)-Gd(2), respectively. The distance between Cu(1) and Gd(2)∗ is 9.213Å.

Magnetic properties of [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)]2⋅3H2O

The temperature dependences of the magnetic susceptibility were measured in the temperature range of 2.0-300.0K under the external magnetic field of 0.5T.   shows the plots of χ M T versus T, where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Cu2Gd2 unit and T is the absolute temperature. The χ M T values at 300.0K are 16.23cm3 Kmol-1, this value being slightly smaller than the calculated value of 16.5cm3 Kmol-1 expected for two CuII (S =1/2, g =2.00) and two GdIII (4f 7, J =7/2, L =0, S =7/2, 8S7/2) non-interacting ions. On lowering the temperature from 300.0K to 2.0K, the χ M T value gradually increases to reach a maximum value of 20.78cm3 Kmol-1 at 6.0K, and then slightly decreases to 19.05cm3 Kmol-1 at 2.0K. The increase of the χ M T value in the higher temperature region indicates the operation of a ferromagnetic interaction between CuII and GdIII ions, while the slight decrease in the lower temperature region can be ascribed to a weak intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction, probably related to the hydrogen bond between two tetrameric units. The 1/χ M versus T plots over the whole temperature range of 2.0-300.0K follow the Curie-Weiss equation of 1/χ M =(T - θ)/C with a positive Weiss constant of θ =+2.8K and C =16.07cm3 Kmol-1.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Since the ground state of the GdIII ion (8S7/2) has no contribution from orbital angular momentum, the magnetic susceptibility of the CuII 2GdIII 2 complex can be reproduced by the equation derived from the spin-only Hamiltonian  H  = g Cu β(S Cu1 + S Cu2) H + g Gd β(S Gd1 + S Gd2)⋅H -2J 1(S Cu1 S Gd1 + S Cu2 S Gd2)-2J 2(S Gd1 S Cu2) based on the coupling scheme for the linear CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII tetranuclear structure, as reported below:   Cu ( 1 )   -     J   1     Gd ( 1 )   -     J   2     Cu ( 2 )   -     J   1     Gd ( 2 )   where g Cu and g Gd are the g-factors for the GdIII and CuII ions, H is the applied magnetic field, J 1 is the Heisenberg coupling constant between the outer and central CuII and GdIII ions (through two phenoxo monoatomic bridges) while J 2 is the Heisenberg coupling constant between the central CuII and GdIII ions (through a three atom N-C-O bridge). Although the linear CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII unit does not show any crystallographic symmetry, the same coupling constant J 1 was assumed for the terminal Cu1-Gd1 and Cu2-Gd2 magnetic interactions on the basis of similar geometric features for these diphenoxo-bridged binuclear subunits. The magnetic susceptibility at each temperature was calculated using the theoretical equation χ = M/H =[NΣi (-dE i/dH)exp(-E i/kT)]/[HΣ i exp(-E i/kT). The energy levels of the tetramer, E i, were evaluated by diagonalizing the Hamiltonian matrix (with dimensions 256×256) in the uncoupled spin function basis set. Moreover, a molecular field term -zJ'< S z > S z was added to the Hamiltonian to describe the molecular interactions between the tetrameric units. Although small, these interactions are necessary to reproduce the decrease in the magnetic moment below 4K. The final expression for the magnetic susceptibility becomes, χ mf = χ/[1- zJ'χ/Ng2β2], where χ is the magnetic susceptibility for the isolated tetramer, calculated as described above.

Preliminary fits performed with this Hamiltonian indicate vanishingly small values of J 2 and large standard errors for this parameter suggest that the magnetic interaction between the central GdIII and CuII ions can be reasonably neglected. This approximation corresponds to the consideration of the tetramer as two independent CuIIGdIII binuclear units and leads to stable four parameter fits in excellent agreement with the experimental magnetic susceptibility data. The solid line in  shows the theoretical curve with the best-fit parameters: g Cu =2.19, g Gd =1.98, J 1 =+2.1cm-1 and zJ'=-0.002cm-1, with an agreement factor R =9.5×10-5. These results indicate that a significant ferromagnetic interaction operates between the CuII and GdIII ions through two phenoxo bridges while a negligible interaction occurs though a three atom N-C-O bridge. The calculated curve with the best-fit parameters is shown in  as the solid line.

cln_elements.clean_text:
The field dependence of the magnetization up to 5T at 2.0K is shown in  , as the plots of M/Nβ versus H. The experimental data per Cu2Gd2 are much higher than the calculated curve of the Brillouin function of S =7/2×2+ S =1/2×2 (independently existing two CuII and two GdIII) and significantly lower than the calculated Brillouin function for a S =8 spin state (with g =2.0) expected from a complete ferromagnetic coupling of all of the ions within the CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII tetramer: see the broken line in . The data are instead quite close to the theoretical curve for two S =4 spin states, the situation expected for the ferromagnetic coupling of the CuII and GdIII ions within two independent CuII-GdIII dimers, in good agreement with the results of the magnetic susceptibility data analysis above. Indeed, a reasonably good fit of the experimental data to the Brillouin function for two S =4 spin states was obtained with g =1.97: see the solid curve in .

It is proper that the magnetic properties of [CuIILdpen(  meso  )GdIII(thd)2(H2O)2]2⋅3H2O are compared with those of [CuIILdpen(1S2S)GdIII(thd)2]1∞ . The (1S,2S) compound has an infinite chain structure of the alternately arrayed CuII and GdIII ions, the Curie-Weiss constant of θ =+8.8K is larger than the meso-compound, and the field-dependent magnetization at 2.0K is larger than the calculated curve of the Brillouin function of the ferromagnetically coupled GdIII-CuII-GdIII-CuII tetramer.

magnetic properties.structure: infinite chain structure of the alternately arrayed CuII and GdIII ions

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp035" view="all">(a) One-dimensional chain structure of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">meso</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">)</ce:sup>(DMF)], running along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis, in which a Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion acts as a connector and the adjacent two molecules with opposite chiralities of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (green) are alternately linked. (b) A view projected onto the coordination planes, showing that the two enantiomers of [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1S,2R)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuL<ce:sup loc="post">dpen(1R,2S)</ce:sup>(DMF)] (green) are alternately arrayed in the 1D chain. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) One-dimensional chain structure of [NaCuLdpen(  meso  )(DMF)], running along the c-axis, in which a Na+ ion acts as a connector and the adjacent two molecules with opposite chiralities of [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] (green) are alternately linked. (b) A view projected onto the coordination planes, showing that the two enantiomers of [NaCuLdpen(1S,2R)(DMF)] (red) and [NaCuLdpen(1R,2S)(DMF)] (green) are alternately arrayed in the 1D chain. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp040" view="all">Molecular structure of a linear Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2) unit with the selected atom numbering scheme. In the linear structure, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same enantiomorphs.</ce:simple-para>

cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Molecular structure of a linear Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) unit with the selected atom numbering scheme. In the linear structure, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same enantiomorphs.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0030">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp045" view="all">A cyclic octanuclear structure formed by the hydrogen bonds through two water molecules (red ball). In the linear structure of the Cu(1)–Gd(1)–Cu(2)–Gd(2) unit, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same chirality (red) and two Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes bridged by hydrogen bonds through water molecule have the opposite chirality (green). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  A cyclic octanuclear structure formed by the hydrogen bonds through two water molecules (red ball). In the linear structure of the Cu(1)-Gd(1)-Cu(2)-Gd(2) unit, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) complexes have the same chirality (red) and two CuII complexes bridged by hydrogen bonds through water molecule have the opposite chirality (green). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp050" view="all">The plots of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> and 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>, where <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The plots of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> follow the Curie–Weiss equation of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>−</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>)/<ce:italic>C</ce:italic> with a positive Weiss constant of <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>16.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The solid line represents the calculated curve with the fitted parameters of <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>(Gd)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.98, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>(Cu)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.19, <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+2.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>zJ</ce:italic>″<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−0.002<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  The plots of χ M T vs. T and 1/χ M vs. T, where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Cu2Gd2. The plots of 1/χ M vs. T follow the Curie-Weiss equation of 1/χ M =(T  -  θ)/C with a positive Weiss constant of θ =+2.8K and C =16.07cm3 Kmol-1. The solid line represents the calculated curve with the fitted parameters of g(Gd)=1.98, g(Cu)=2.19, J =+2.1cm-1, zJ"=-0.002cm-1, and R =5×10-5.

<ce:caption>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8 (ferromagnetic coupled tetramer (Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>)), <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (two ferromagnetic coupled Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>), and <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (independently existing two Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and two Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>) are drawn from the top line, and all calculation were performed with <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>197.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  The field dependence of the magnetization per Cu2Gd2 up to 5T at 2.0K, as the plots of M/Nβ vs. H. The calculated curves of M/Nβ vs. H with the Brillouin functions of S =8 (ferromagnetic coupled tetramer (CuII-GdIII-CuII-GdIII)), S =4×2 (two ferromagnetic coupled CuII-GdIII), and S =7/2×2+ S =1/2×2 (independently existing two CuII and two GdIII) are drawn from the top line, and all calculation were performed with g =197.
